title: 111_s840
content: The Act is titled the "International Clean Energy Development Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines "Asia-Pacific Partnership" as the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate. It also defines "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The House of Representatives defines "clean and efficient energy technology" as technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase energy efficiency, or decrease energy usage intensity. Greenhouse gases include carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. The Asia-Pacific Partnership defines "Partnership Task Forces" as task forces established under their program. The term "Program Office" refers to the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate Program Office of the Department of State. Establishment of Development and Commercialization Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies. The Secretary of State will establish a Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies comprised of technical and policy experts from various government departments and agencies. The Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies, established by the Secretary of State, includes representatives from various government departments and agencies. The Committee's duties involve reviewing and evaluating information on clean and efficient energy technologies, including action plans developed by the Partnership. The Secretary of State will designate a Chairperson or co-Chairpersons from employees of the Department of State. The Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies, established by the Secretary of State, prioritizes projects for developing and commercializing clean and efficient energy technologies. They plan and execute projects through established protocols, require cost-sharing from project participants, and regularly report progress to congressional committees. The Secretary of State established the Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies to prioritize projects for developing and commercializing clean and efficient energy technologies. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, a strategy report must be submitted to congressional committees outlining collaboration efforts among various stakeholders for this purpose. The Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies aims to prioritize projects for renewable energy, power generation, and cleaner fossil energy. It focuses on developing members' capacity to utilize these technologies and encourages their transfer to non-member countries. Project participants are required to continue utilizing these technologies. The Committee on Clean and Efficient Energy Technologies prioritizes projects for renewable energy, power generation, and cleaner fossil energy. Project participants must match funding provided by the United States dollar-for-dollar to increase project value for participants and taxpayers. SEC. 4. REPORT BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE. The Secretary of State must provide an annual report to congressional committees on the implementation of the Act, detailing project results, actions taken by the Committee, review of clean energy technologies, and advancement of priority projects. An annual report must be provided to congressional committees on the implementation of the Act, detailing project results, actions taken by the Committee, review of clean energy technologies, and advancement of priority projects. This includes identifying and describing priorities for promoting clean and efficient energy technologies within the Asia-Pacific Partnership countries, assessing private sector involvement, and making recommendations to streamline Federal programs and policies. Federal programs and policies aim to enhance the involvement of Federal departments and agencies in developing and commercializing clean and efficient energy technologies globally. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of State to carry out the Act is set at $200,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014.
